page_analysis.text_content:
Setbacks

Setbacks
apportion a
lot into two
parts:
• buildable area
(in the middle)
• required yards
(surrounding the
building area).

These required yards,
meant to be maintained
as open space areas, are
important as landscaping
opportunities to keep our
neighborhoods attractive
as well as for the preser-
vation of privacy.

Code sections
Page 20
18.12.040 (a) Table 2
18.12.040 (a,c,e,& i)
Page 21
18.04.040 (e)
Page 22–23
18.040.030 (84, 87, 91,
128, & 146)
Page 24–25
as shown in table
20

Standard setbacks

Standard setbacks apply in most
cases.

*

For front setback, if contextual setback is greater than 30'
then it applies—otherwise, the 20' setback applies.

*

For front & street side setbacks a special setback may apply.
If both a contextual and special setback apply, the greater of
the two setbacks is required.

Special setbacks

Special setbacks override standard
setbacks unless a larger contextual
setback applies.

Streets w/special setbacks

Special setback distances can be found on:

• pages of the city's zone-map booklet (available both online
and in hardback at the Development Center)

• parcel reports from the city's GIS (available at the Develop-
ment Center)

visual_elements.description: A small, empty white rectangle representing a lot, positioned next to the text 'apportion a lot into two parts:'. It visually implies the concept of dividing a lot.

A table titled 'Standard setbacks by zone' with columns for 'Zone District', 'Front', 'Rear', 'Interior Side', and 'Street Side'. It lists setback requirements for various R-1 zones, Flag lots, and Substandard lots.
A list of street names under the heading 'Streets w/special setbacks', organized into three columns.

technical_specifications.parameter: Substandard corner lot < 50' wide Front Setback
Substandard corner lot < 50' wide Rear Setback
Substandard corner lot < 50' wide Interior Side Setback
Substandard corner lot < 50' wide Street Side Setback

subheadings: Standard setbacks apply in most cases.
Special setbacks override standard setbacks unless a larger contextual setback applies.
sections: Setbacks apportion a lot into two parts:
These required yards, meant to be maintained as open space areas, are important as landscaping opportunities to keep our neighborhoods attractive as well as for the preservation of privacy.
Special setback distances can be found on:

additional_notes: Page number '20' is at the bottom left.
Asterisk symbols (*) are used next to 'Front' and 'Street Side' in the 'Standard setbacks by zone' table header, and are explained in two bulleted notes below the table.
The 'R-1(8000) Rear' setback value has an apostrophe (20') which might indicate feet, but is inconsistent with other numerical values in the table.
cross_references: city's zone-map booklet (available both online and in hardback at the Development Center)
parcel reports from the city's GIS (available at the Development Center)
